list_definition.definition: obstinate, or unwilling to yield, obey etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He’s as stubborn as a donkey.

list_ex_of_english: She loves his tweedy smell, his steady gaze, his dark hair, his stubborn mouth.
But conversely, there is something in the past that demands recognition in its stubborn strangeness, that requires the adjustment of our categorizations.
Of course, if they admit the former view, they reveal themselves as historicists, albeit stubborn and principled ones.
The conjunction of precedence, consistency, and exclusivity gives rise to the strong and stubborn conviction that will can cause action.
Big expectations and premature triumphs gave way to misgivings, stubborn skepticism prevailed.
Yet stubborn purists will still try to instil a pre-eminent appreciation for the original written works.
The amount of technical expertise and sheer stubborn patience required to comprehend analyses of the internal structures of classical music is formidable.
They are less often described as 'aggressive, stubborn, disobedient' than their siblings.
